div.head: AUGUST 25th.
div.p: THE Pre≈øident, Members and Judge Advocate being ≈øworn, the Judge Advocate pro≈øecuting in the name of the United States of America, the Court proceed to the trial of Major General St. Clair, who appears before the Court, and the following charges, contained in a Report of a Committee of Congre≈øs appointed to examine the evidence collected, and to ≈øtate charges again≈øt the General Officers who were in the Northern Department when Ticonderoga and Mount Independence were evacuated, are exhibited again≈øt him.
Fir≈øt. With neglect of duty, under the 5th article of the 18th ≈øection of the Rules and Articles of War.
Second. With cowardice, with treachery, with incapacity as a General, re≈øpectively; under the 5th article of the 18th ≈øection of the Rules and Articles of War.
Third. With treachery, under the 5th article of the 18th ≈øection of the Rules and Articles of War.

Fifth. With ≈øhamefully abandoning the po≈øts of Ticonderoga and Mount Independence, in his charge; under the 12th article of the 13th ≈øection of the Rules and Articles of War.
Major General ST. CLAIR pleads NOT GUILTY.
The Judge Advocate ≈øtates the matters upon which the charges again≈øt the General are founded, as follow:

IT is nece≈ø≈øary (previous to my producing the requi≈øite evidence on this trial) that I ≈øhould inform you of the matters, upon which the charges again≈øt Major General St. Clair are founded. They are certain remarks, made by a committee of the Hon. the Continental Congre≈øs, appointed to examine the evidence collected, and to ≈øtate charges again≈øt the general officers who were in the northern department when Ticonderoga and Mount Independence were evacuated.

Before I mention the≈øe remarks, I would inform you that Major General St. Clair, on or about the 13th day of June, 1777, took upon him the command of Ticonderoga and Mount Independence, and that the≈øe places were evacuated to the enemy by his orders on the 6th day of July following.

The fir≈øt remark is: That on the 13th day of June General St. Clair was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of an information from two pri≈øoners taken in Canada, that the Briti≈øh forces, amounting to about 10,000 men, were proceeding as fa≈øt as po≈ø≈øible again≈øt him, and that he might expect their arrival in three weeks at farthe≈øt. That as on the 18th of June four of the enemy's ve≈ø≈øels were lying on the hither ≈øide of Split Rock, and on the 24th ≈øeven of them were at Crown-Point, and others four or five miles lower down, their forces then encamped on both ≈øides of Gilleland's Creek, and he was informed by his ≈øcouts that they were very numerous; ≈øo from the≈øe circum≈øtances it appears General St. Clair had ≈øub≈øtantial rea≈øon to confide in what the pri≈øoners had told him
relative to the intentions and ≈øtrength of the enemy; and that he ought at this time to have taken his final re≈øolution, either to ≈øtand an attack, or to retreat with his ≈øtores, the pre≈øervation of which was a principal object in the determination of a council of war on the 20th of June. Therefore it appears that General St. Clair's neglecting to form his deci≈øive opinion at this time, or at a later day, ≈øo as to allow him a ≈øufficient opportunity to retreat with his troops, ≈øick, ammunition, cannon, provi≈øions and cloathing, and to deprive the enemy of ≈øhelter at Ticonderoga, was a neglect of duty.

Second. That General St. Clair, on the 24th of June, was informed by his ≈øcouts the enemy were very numerous and yet, neverthele≈øs, on the next day he wrote to Congre≈øs, that he was not able to di≈øcover whether the enemy were in force or not.

Third. That if General St. Clair found ≈ømall ≈øcouts could not acquire a knowledge whether the enemy were in force or not, it was his duty in due time to have ≈øent out reconnoitering parties, in ≈øuch force as might have a≈ø≈øured him whether or not the enemy were in ≈øtrength, this being a mo≈øt important point, as upon this he was to regulate his motions; and therefore his failure in ≈øending out ≈øuch parties in due time was a neglect of duty.

Fourth. That as Je≈ø≈øe Leavenworth ≈øwears General St. Clair did not annoy the enemy in their advance again≈øt, and inve≈øtiture of, the po≈øts under his care, although the troops were healthy, courageous, and „Äà‚óä„Äâ of action, it appears the General did not to the utmo≈øt of his power oppo≈øe the operations of the enemy; and therefore that he is liable to the charge of neglect of duty, of cowardice, or of treachery, or of incapacity as a General.

Fifth. That as it was determined in a council of war on the twentieth of June, approved by General Schuyler, the commanding officer in the department, that the repairing the old and adding new works on Mount Independence ought to claim immediate attention; and Je≈ø≈øe Leavenworth ≈øwears not a ≈øtroke was ≈øtruck for tho≈øe purpo≈øes; and by the orderly book it appears the fatigue party was decrea≈øed in number, and continued ≈øo at a time when it ≈øhould have been abundantly increa≈øed; ≈øo on the≈øe points the General is liable to be charged with a neglect of duty, amounting to a breach of orders, and with treachery.

Sixth. That as on the 25th of May, the Deputy Commi≈ø≈øary rated that 1400 barrels of flour would, at an allowance of one pound each man per diem, ≈øerve 4000 men 66 days, and that 661 barrels of beef would ≈øerve the ≈øame number of men 75 days; and ≈øuppo≈øing that, from the twentieth of June to the fourth of July inclu≈øive, there were in Ticonderoga and Mount Independence 4739 men, and there does not appear to have been at any time between the≈øe periods a greater number; ≈øo e≈øtimating the con≈øumption of 4739 men, from the twentieth of June to the fourth of July inclu≈øive, upon the 2015 barrels of flour, 195 barrels of beef, and 784 barrels of pork, on the twentieth of June returned by Deputy Commi≈ø≈øary Yancey as then actually remaining on hand, there did on the fourth of July remain, or ought, if provi≈øions had been regularly and properly i≈ø≈øued, to be then remaining 1625 barrels of flour, 3 barrels of beef, and 784 barrels of pork; a magazine of provi≈øions ≈øufficient to afford to the army on the fifth of July, amounting, by the arrival of the militia of the Grants, to 5639 men of all ranks, fall allowance of provi≈øion in flour for 52 days, and in beef and pork for 32 days, exclu≈øive of the con≈øiderable number of fat cattle that arrived at Ticonderoga on the fifth of July, the teams of oxen nece≈ø≈øarily attending the po≈øt, and other ≈øtores ≈øpecified in the Commi≈ø≈øary's return on the twentieth of June, and even ≈øuppo≈øing, as may not rea≈øonably be done, that no ≈øupply of flour had arrived after that day. And as this calculation has been liberally made, upon the quantity of provi≈øions actually in Ticonderoga on the twentieth of June, for the expenditure of which General St. Clair, as commander at the po≈øt, ought to be held re≈øpon≈øible; therefore it clearly appears Ticonderoga and Mount Independence were not abandoned upon the ju≈øt principle of a want of provi≈øions.

Seventh. That as General St. Clair informed the Hon. Mr. Jay, that at the time of holding the council of war on the 5th of July he knew it to be impo≈ø≈øible to defend the po≈øts with his numbers, it is natural to conclude he was decided upon this point as early as the 29th of June, the day that he ≈øent his ≈øon and private effects from Ticonderoga to Fort-George, as a place of ≈øafety: That being decided upon this point, it was his duty then to have taken as effectual mea≈øures for the pre≈øervation of the public property, at lea≈øt equally with his own, claiming his earlie≈øt attention: That on the 30th of June, the enemy being advancing again≈øt him ≈øo near as the Three-mile-point, it is incredible that he did not then know that they were in force: That it was his duty, at that point of time, to have finally determined either to abide the operations of the enemy, or to retire: That if the la≈øt re≈øolution was taken, and, from his ≈øending off his ≈øon and baggage the day before, there is the ≈øtronge≈øt pre≈øumption that this re≈øolution was then fully taken, it was his duty then to have proceeded to ≈øend off the public ≈øtores, to de≈øtroy the works, and to evacuate the po≈øts without lo≈øing a moment of time: And that by deferring to take any mea≈øures to retire till the la≈øt moment when he could po≈ø≈øibly retreat even with his effective troops, a moment when the ≈øick, ammunition, cannon, provi≈øion and cloathing of the army mu≈øt be abandoned and lo≈øt, be≈øides the lives of many men in effecting a retreat from before an enemy immediately upon him, General St. Clair appears chargeable with inattention to the progre≈øs of the enemy, with treachery, or with incapacity as a General, and with ≈øhamefully abandoning the po≈øts of Ticonderoga and Mount Independence, in his charge. Nor can the proving, as General St. Clair wi≈øhes to do, that the works of Ticonderoga and Mount Independence were too exten≈øive, and that the troops were very badly armed, if ≈øuch things can be proved, fail of placing General St. Clair in a more reprehen≈øible point of view, as the weakne≈øs of his defence being more obvious, his retreat ≈øhould have been the earlier determined upon.

The charge of neglect of duty is founded on the fir≈øt, third, fourth and fifth remarks re≈øpectively.‚Äî Cowardice, treachery, incapacity as a General, re≈øpectively, are founded upon the fourth remark.‚Äî Treachery, founded upon the fifth remark.‚ÄîInattention to the progre≈øs of the enemy, treachery, incapacity as a General, re≈øpectively, founded upon the ≈øeventh remark.‚ÄîShamefully abandoning the po≈øts of Ticonderoga and Mount Independence, in his charge, founded upon the ≈øeventh remark.

div.p: The letters being read, Major General St. Clair addre≈ø≈øes the Court as follows:
THE re≈øolution that has ju≈øt been read is of ≈øo ≈øingular a nature, that I cannot pa≈øs it by without ≈øome ob≈øervations.

The treatment I have received renders it nece≈ø≈øary for me to ≈øubmit to any regulation that may have been pre≈øcribed, as an objection on my part would probably be con≈øtrued into the fear of a thorough inve≈øtigation, and con≈øequently an evidence of guilt. The Judge Advocate produces copies of letters from Major General St. Clair to Major General Schuyler, dated June 13th, June 18th, and June 24th, 1777; al≈øo a copy of a letter from Major General St. Clair to Congre≈øs, dated June 25th, 1777; a copy of a letter from General St. Clair to Major General Schuyler, dated June 30th, 1777; the proceedings of a Council of Officers held at Ticonderoga the 20th of June, 1777; a ≈øtate of the guards and fatigue party, June 15th, 1777, from a copy of General St. Clair's orderly book; al≈øo an order from the ≈øaid orderly book re≈øpecting the guards and fatigue party, June 23d, 1777: which, being read, are as follow:

body.p: HERE follows the ≈øub≈øtance of the information given by two men from Canada, taken pri≈øoners by one of our parties on Onion River.

That General Burgoyne it arrived in Canada, but has brought no troops with him; that the Briti≈øh army is a≈ø≈øembling as fa≈øt as po≈ø≈øible at St. John's; that the light infantry, which they call the flying army, commanded by General Frazer, is already advanced to Point-au-Fer; that the whole army is ≈øaid to con≈øi≈øt of about ten thou≈øand men, a part of which, with Indians under the command of Sir John John≈øon, and Canadians under Captain Mackay, are to penetrate the country by the Mohawk River whil≈øt the re≈øt of the army under General Burgoyne cro≈ø≈øes the Lake to attack this place; that their fleet (a particular account of which is in the inclo≈øed letter to General Sullivan) is all in the Lake, and we may depend on their being here in a fortnight at farthe≈øt.

From the nature and circum≈øtance of the pa≈øs granted to one of the two, which I here inclo≈øe, and his own account of the manner in which he was ≈øent from Montreal, viz. to ≈øearch plans of the country which he pretended to know are hid at Metcalf's, and his being po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of a con≈øiderable ≈øum of continental money, and ≈øome gold and ≈øilver, I have the ≈øtronge≈øt ≈øu≈øpicion of his being a ≈øpy, and have ≈øecured him „Äà‚óä„Äâ ≈øuch, and ≈øent him down to you, both that you might have an opportunity to examine him your≈øelf, and that, if you ≈øhould think of him as I do, he might be tried at Albany, where, ≈øhould he be found guilty, the ≈øentence will probably be more adequate to the crime than here; for I find the officer, who lately ≈øuffered a ≈øpy he had in charge to e≈øcape, through the gro≈ø≈øe≈øt mi≈øconduct, has been honourably acquited by a Court Martial.

Though their intelligence differs very materially, they agree in the circum≈øtance of General Burgoyne's arrival; and if the≈øe fellows have really been ≈øent by him to ≈øee what we were about, there was no method more likely to procure them an ea≈øy reception than that of giving an account of the preparations in Canada, and carrying, or pretending to carry, letters from our friends. Baldwin ≈øays, will be all ≈øunk by the end of next week; in the mean time I have ordered the floating bridge to be removed to the lower ≈øide of them, which will ≈øerve as a kind of ≈øecond boom, and retard at lea≈øt, if not prevent, the enemy's ve≈ø≈øels from pa≈ø≈øing, ≈øhould they attempt it.

The tents here are in general very bad. I mu≈øt beg you, my dear General, to ha≈øten up the new tents, for I ≈øhall get no good of the troops here in any way, whil≈øt they remain in barracks.

Our powder magazines are in ≈øo wretched a ≈øtate, that I am told near fifty pounds of powder a week is damaged. In ≈øhort, every thing is ≈øo much out of order, that I will add no more to this lift of grievances, than to tell you we have no cartridge paper.

postscript.p: I forgot to mention a paper in which Am≈øbury's money was wrapped and is al≈øo inclo≈øed; it is blurred and blotted, but you will ob≈øerve it contains a letter from Eph. Jones to his brother, dated June 2d, about the time Am≈øbury left Montreal, and is a corroborating circum≈øtance of the fellow's ill de≈øign.

I ≈øhould have called upon the militia but for the ≈øtate of our magazine.‚ÄîShould they come in fa≈øt, which I believe they would, they might eat us out before either the arrival of the enemy or a ≈øupply.‚Äî Plea≈øe to give your directions on this head as ≈øoon as po≈ø≈øible.

body.p: INCLOSED you have the returns of the troops and ≈øtores at this place, all except the cloathier's, which is ≈øo drained I thought it needle≈øs to a≈øk for any from him, as he has almo≈øt literally nothing.

Since my la≈øt I have had con≈øtant ≈øcouts out, but have made no di≈øcovery of the enemy, ≈øave that four of their ve≈ø≈øels are lying about a mile on the hither ≈øide of the Split Rock; they con≈øi≈øt of two ≈øhips, and two gondolas; and on Friday la≈øt a ≈øchooner beat up within four miles of Crown-Point, but, without landing any of her people, or coming to anchor, returned down the lake.

Ye≈øterday about noon we had two men, who had ≈øtrolled out of camp without arms, taken by a party of ≈øavages, who had ≈øtole down to the road ≈øide betwixt M'lnto≈øh's and the bridge, and concealed them≈øelves in the bu≈øhes; they were immediately pur≈øued as far as Putnam's Creek, but could not be over-taken; unluckily, however, they fell in with a ≈øcouting party I had ≈øent down to di≈øcover the motions of the enemy, that were upon their return, and fired upon them unexpectedly; the officer is wounded, one man killed and ≈øcalped, and one mi≈ø≈øing, but whether taken or not is as yet uncertain.

Another party that I had ordered to proceed to Point-au-Fer, or wherever the enemy might be, returned la≈øt night on di≈øcovering a large party of Indians on the ea≈øt ≈øide of the lake about four miles above Crown-Point. I think of ≈øending to feel their pul≈øe to-night, as I am ≈øure it would be of con≈øequences to give tho≈øe fellows a drubbing.

I am at a lo≈øs to form a judgment of the de≈øigns of the enemy. If they mean to attack us, one would think it indi≈øcreet to put us on our guard by ≈øuch a trifling affair, and yet I cannot think they could prevail with any number of the ≈øavages to come on, unle≈øs they had an army not far off to ≈øupport them. Be „Äà‚óä„Äâ as it will, I ≈øhall u≈øe every precaution po≈ø≈øible again≈øt ≈øurprize and will endeavour to penetrate their de≈øigns. The ≈øame rea≈øon, notwith≈øtanding our weakne≈øs, ≈øtill prevails again≈øt calling for the militia as when I wrote la≈øt, having as yet received no ≈øupply of meat either fre≈øh or ≈øalt.

Do you know, Sir, any thing about the terms upon which Capt. Whitcomb's corps was rai≈øed. He informs me, that by General Gates's orders he promi≈øed his people that they ≈øhould have the ≈øame bounty as the troops of the ≈øtate in which they were rai≈øed, notwith≈øtanding they were not part of their quota. This promi≈øe has not been complied with, and they are held by a conditional agreement only, which expires this day. I ≈øhall be able to retain them, however, until you favour me with your an≈øwer.

I am making ≈øome improvement upon the Mount, but that and the Ticonderoga ≈øide have ≈øuch dependence upon, and connection with, each other, that in my opinion it will be very dangerous to give up either, and yet it is certain we cannot with our pre≈øent numbers hold both. I de≈øign, however, to make the appearance of doing it, and after defending Ticonderoga as long as po≈ø≈øible retreat to Mount Independence.
Our guards are crouded with tories; they are dangerous here, and cannot properly be tried. I have ordered them to Albany.

postscript.p: The bridge goes on heavily, the ca≈ø≈øoons not all ≈øunk yet, but the timber is almo≈øt all cut, and in the water.
The officers of the fleet have not received commi≈ø≈øions, and are very unea≈øy about it.

body.p: SERJEANT HEATH, who I ≈øent down the Lake to make di≈øcoveries, returned la≈øt night, and informs me, that on Tue≈øday la≈øt he ≈øaw two birch canoes going down the Lake with ≈øixteen Indians and three white men in them, and ≈øuppo≈øes it was the party that had done the mi≈øchief near the lines the day before‚Äîthat, from a place near the mouth of Otter Creek, he ≈øaw three ve≈ø≈øels under ≈øail beating up, one at anchor about one mile above Split Rock, and the Thunderer behind it‚Äîfrom this place he likewi≈øe de≈øcried an encampment of the enemy on both ≈øides of Gilliland's Creek‚Äîthat from the appearance of it, and the extent, he thinks it mu≈øt contain a great body of men, and that a number of ≈ømoaks aro≈øe at a di≈øtance back, which he ≈øuppo≈øed was from the encampment of the Indians,‚Äîthat on Friday la≈øt, from Pointon, he ≈øaw twenty batteaus come out of Gilliland's Creek, and ≈øail up the Lake pa≈øt the Split Rock towards Ticonderoga‚Äîthat one of the inhabitants in whom he could place confidence informed him the Indians were very numerous‚Äîthat they frequently cro≈øs to the ea≈øt ≈øide of the Lake, and that a party of them had been at his hou≈øe a few minutes before his arrival‚Äîthat he then returned to Otter-Creek, where he propo≈øed to have halted to refre≈øh his party, but on being informed that a large party of Indians were at one Briton's, he made the be≈øt of his way here‚Äîone of his party this day fell behind a little, and was either taken or de≈øerted; he ≈øu≈øpects the latter, becau≈øe he both waited for him, and ≈øent back to look for him‚Äîthat one Webb, another inhabitant, informed him that the enemy had been four or five days at Gilliland's‚Äî that they came up with a va≈øt number of batteaux and ≈øome gondolas‚Äîthat ≈øome of the troops come over frequently, and ≈øay their whole army is there, and that they are only waiting the arrival of the re≈øt of their ve≈ø≈øels and ≈øtores, when they are to attack this place.

I have no doubt that a party of the enemy are at Gilliland's, nor that their de≈øign is to come here, but not in my opinion to attack, but to harra≈øs us, and give confidence to their ≈øavages, who, it is more than probable, would not have been prevailed upon to undertake it without being joined by ≈øome regular troops. Were they in force, it is improbable they would wa≈øte their time at ≈øuch a di≈øtance, in a part of the country where they can find nothing to refre≈øh them≈øelves; and I do not find that they have made any depredations on the ea≈øt ≈øide.

It is not ea≈øy to judge of the force at a di≈øtant view of an encampment, and Heath mu≈øt have been ≈øix miles or more di≈øtant from that on Gilliland's Point, a di≈øtance too great to determine any thing with preci≈øion, although he had a gla≈øs to a≈ø≈øi≈øt his eye; be≈øides, I think the ground is not capable of encamping a great number (for he in≈øi≈øts on it they are not upon the high ground, but upon the beach only) but of this you are a much better judge than me, as I never ≈øaw it but once: Be the matter as it will, I ≈øhall endeavour to guard again≈øt ≈øurprize, and to di≈øcover both them and their de≈øigns; and, if opportunity offers, feel their pul≈øes a little.

I had all the ground between this and Crown-Point, from the Lake ≈øome di≈øtance over the mountains, well examined ye≈øterday with a heavy ≈øcout, but they di≈øcovered no enemy, nor appearance of any: Whitcomb ≈øays he is certain there has not been an Indian but three in that quarter ≈øince the pri≈øoners were taken, and that it was three or four days ≈øince the≈øe three had been there; ≈øo that the Indians ≈øaid to have been about us, and fired at, were, I believe, the children of a di≈øturbed imagination.

You had an exceeding bad time to cro≈øs the Lake, but I hope you got well over, and without any injury to your health, though it mu≈øt have been expo≈øed, as I doubt if you were not obliged to be out a ≈øecond night. I ≈øhall write again to you by expre≈øs the moment I make any farther di≈øcoveries; and am, with much re≈øpect and e≈øteem,

closer.signed: Your mo≈øt obedient humble Servant, A. ST. CLAIR.

body.p: I INCLOSE you a return of the troops at this po≈øt, by which you will ≈øee that our effective numbers are very little more than two thou≈øand, a force greatly inadequate to its defence, which, ≈øhould the enemy attack it in force, would require at lea≈øt four times that number. In that two thou≈øand are included a number of artificers, who are unarmed, and many of the ≈øoldiers are in the ≈øame condition, and the whole in very great want of cloathing, accoutrements and bayonets.

The intelligence I have received of the enemy's approaching, I have from time to time tran≈ømitted to General Schuyler, of which I make no doubt he has appri≈øed Congre≈øs. It is now pa≈øt a doubt that they are moving towards us, but whether in force or not I have not yet been able to di≈øcover. Seven of their ve≈ø≈øels came up to Crown-Point la≈øt night, and others of their fleet are about three or four miles lower down, as we judge from their morning guns. They have al≈øo landed ≈øome troops, who are encamped upon Chimney-Point, which lies on the ea≈øt ≈øide of the Lake, directly oppo≈øite to Crown-Point. If the militia were called in, they might po≈ø≈øibly enable us to keep po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, but I have not yet ventured upon that ≈øtep, on account of the low ≈øtate of our provi≈øions, there not being more than thirty-five days meat tor the troops now here, and the uncertainty in which we were with regard to the enemy's de≈øigns.

No army was ever in a more critical ≈øituation than we now are; and, ≈øuppo≈øing that this motion is only a feint to favour the operations of General Howe, which I ≈øtill ≈øu≈øpect it to be, we may, and probably will, be reduced to the greate≈øt di≈øtre≈øs, the ≈øupplies being derived from ≈øuch a di≈øtance, and the communication ≈øo difficult, that it is next to impo≈ø≈øible to ≈øupport it. The exten≈øivene≈øs of our works adds greatly to our embarra≈ø≈øment, and will demand ≈øo great con≈øtant guards, as mu≈øt in a very ≈øhort time wear down our troops, and do the enemy's bu≈øine≈øs for them; and ≈øhould we give up one ≈øide of the Lake, and confine our≈øelves to the defence of the other, they would infallibly cut off our communication, and reduce us by famine.

My duty to my country, and to my≈øelf, obliges me to make the≈øe repre≈øentations; neverthele≈øs, I ≈øhall leave nothing undone within my power to fru≈øtrate the attempts of the enemy, nor leave any means untried to penetrate their real de≈øigns. body.p: THIS morning ≈øome of the enemy's gun boats appeared at the Three Mile Point, when the alarm was given. That although our force may be adequate to maintain our ground on Mount Independence, yet, unle≈øs a ≈øufficient ≈øtock of provi≈øion can be thrown in before the arrival of the enemy, we having now only thirty-nine days provi≈øion of meat kind, we think it would be imprudent to expo≈øe the army to be made pri≈øoners by the enemy; and that, therefore, it is prudent to provide for a retreat, to effectuate which, that all the batteaus now at this po≈øt be immediately repaired, and as many as can be ≈øpared out of the Lake George be brought hither.

div.p: GENERAL ST. General St. Clair's que≈øtion. Do you recollect the purport?

The Judge Advocate produces ≈øeveral extracts from a copy of General St. Clair's orderly book, which, being read, are as follow:
General St. CLAIR'S ORDERS.

div.p: All the troops who have their mu≈øquets loaded are ordered to di≈øcharge them immediately after roll-call; the officers will ≈øee the arms properly cleaned.

A ≈øcout, con≈øi≈øting of a ≈øubaltern, ≈øerjeant, and twenty privates, to be alternately furni≈øhed by the brigades on each ≈øide of the Lake, and to be ≈øent out every morning, one hour before gun fire.

Mr. Leavenworth, being ≈øworn, ≈øays: I arrived at Ticonderoga the 9th of March, and tarried there until the retreat. About three weeks before the retreat, as near as I can remember, it was reported that the enemy were at Split Rock, and I heard guns ≈øome days that were ≈øaid to be their evening and morning guns. I al≈øo heard General St. Clair give out he thought that the enemy were between ≈øix and ≈øeven thou≈øand ≈øtrong. On the 26th of June I made report to General St. Clair of the tallow in my po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, the quantity being great. He ≈øaid he would give directions about it, and ≈øaid al≈øo that the Commi≈ø≈øary ought to have taken care of it, and had it worked up. General St. Clair took occa≈øion to mention that the Commi≈ø≈øary had not only neglected his duty in that in≈øtance, but al≈øo had neglected it in not ≈øending on the ≈øupplies of provi≈øion. I did not hear any thing more about it, and on Wedne≈øday before the retreat I went to General St. Clair re≈øpecting it, who ≈øaid it was the Commi≈ø≈øary's bu≈øine≈øs, and he ought to have taken care of it, and blamed him again on account of provi≈øion, and ≈øaid there were but a few days provi≈øion. I told him I thought there was more. All the provi≈øion had been removed from Ticonderoga to Mount Independence, and on Thur≈øday or Friday I went to Mount Independence to ≈øatisfy my≈øelf re≈øpecting the quantity of provi≈øion there, and I think there were full three thou≈øand barrels of beef, pork and flour there, from the appearance of them. I did not count them. This was a larger quantity than appeared to be there on the twenty-≈øixth of June. On Wedne≈øday before the retreat I was at Head-Quarters, and ob≈øerved it was entirely ≈øtripped of the baggage, and in con≈øequence of it I put my baggage in a boat, and ≈øent it to Mount Independence. Having received no orders about the tallow, I de≈øired ≈øome gentlemen to ≈øpeak to the General about it, and on Saturday morning the enemy made their appearance on Mount Defiance, when, talking to ≈øome gentlemen re≈øpecting the tallow, one of them ≈øaid I had done enough to exculpate my≈øelf re≈øpecting it, and gave me to under≈øtand that we were to retreat that evening, and told me not to let it be known by words or actions, and told me not to regulate my conduct by it ≈øo that it might be known. It was General Poor who told me of it. On Saturday evening, at gun firing, I went into my boat with my people, and went to the ≈øouth-we≈øt point of Mount Independence, and I continued in my boat and on the point of Mount Independence all night. Between eleven and twelve o'clock at night, one Serjeant Bond came down, who told me that he came down to ≈øee what boats were there. That between twelve and one o'clock, a party of men came down to the Scotchman's, and took the boats up to the Crane, as they ≈øaid, to load with provi≈øion, and at day light began to return, and I went off with my boat in company with the fir≈øt boats. The cannon began to be removed (when General Schuyler was pre≈øent) from Ticonderoga to Mount Independence, and continued to be removed after General Schuyler's departure, as were quantities of artillery ≈øtores.
Q. Did any quantity of provi≈øion arrive at Ticonderoga or Mount Independence from the 20th of June to the time of the evacuation, either from Fort George or Skeen≈øborough!
A. Not to my knowledge.

Q. Court. What rea≈øon had you to think the troops were healthy, courageous, and de≈øirous of improving every advantage again≈øt the enemy?

A. In the fir≈øt place, with regard to their being healthy, I had occa≈øion to be at the ho≈øpital ≈øeveral times after the enemy came near to us, and I did not ≈øee many ≈øick there, and it was generally reported that the army was healthy. General St. Clair's que≈øtion. You have mentioned ≈øeveral times that I gave out that the enemy were between 6 and 7000 ≈øtrong. I ≈øhould be glad to know whether it was to you I told it, or how you came to be acquainted with it?

A. Upon ≈øome of the men ≈øaying that their times were nearly out, I told them they mu≈øt ≈øtay longer if there was an occa≈øion for it. body.p: NOT finding a convenient opportunity to ≈øend off my letter, I have the plea≈øure to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 28th. body.p: YESTERDAY at noon, in the very in≈øtant of the feu-de-joye, which con≈øi≈øted of thirteen pieces of cannon (the mu≈øketry might have di≈øcovered to the enemy our numbers) forty-one batteaus appeared of me Three Mile Point, cro≈ø≈øed the Lake, and landed troops on the ea≈øt ≈øide, in the Bay formed behind the Long Point, oppo≈øite to the Three Mile Point. I am in great pain for the batteaus and ≈øtores at the Landing. The inhabitants who live between this and the bridge, I found it nece≈ø≈øary to bring within the lines, and have now ≈øent them to Skeen≈øborough, with directions to Captain Gray to forward them to Albany by the fir≈øt opportunity. body.p: CONGRESS may probably think it extraordinary that ≈øo much time ≈øhould have elap≈øed before they heard from me, after a ≈øtep of ≈øuch con≈øequence as the evacuation of the po≈øts that had been entru≈øted to my care, but it was not in my power to write whil≈øt on the march to this place. I am ≈øorry to find that my letter to General Schuyler, the night the evacuation took place, has not come to his hands; as, for want of that, tho' he has doubtle≈øs informed Congre≈øs of the matter, he could not give them the rea≈øons that induced it. They were the≈øe:

Seeing that the po≈øts of Ticonderoga and Mount Independence were nearly inve≈øted, and having intelligence by my ≈øpies that they would be compleatly ≈øo in twenty-four hours, when we ≈øhould be cut off from all po≈ø≈øibility of ≈øuccour; that the batteries of the enemy were ready to open, and the whole of our encampment, on the Ticonderoga ≈øide, expo≈øed to their fire; con≈øidering, at the ≈øame time, the weakne≈øs of the garri≈øon, that the effective numbers were not ≈øufficient to man one half of the works, and that, con≈øequently, the whole mu≈øt be upon con≈øtant duty, which they could not po≈ø≈øibly long ≈øu≈øtain, and that of cour≈øe the places, with the garri≈øon, mu≈øt inevitably in a very few days fall into the enemy's hands; I ≈øaw no alternative but endeavouring to evacuate them and bring off the army. Whereupon I called the General Officers together, to take their ≈øentiments. They were unanimou≈øly of opinion that the places ≈øhould be evacuated without the lea≈øt lo≈øs of time; and it was accordingly ≈øet about that night, the 5th in≈øtant, after embarking in boats as much of our cannon, provi≈øion and ≈øtores, as was po≈ø≈øible.

With the boats, which were ordered to Skeen≈øborough, I ≈øent Colonel Long, an active, diligent, good officer, to take the command there, with his regiment and the invalids, until I ≈øhould join him with the army, which was to march to that place by Ca≈øtle-Town. Two regiments of militia, who had left us the evening before, and halted about two miles from Colonel Warner, were immediately ordered to his a≈ø≈øi≈øtance; but, to my great ≈øurprize, they marched directly down to me. At the ≈øame time I received information that the enemy were in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Skeen≈øborough, and had cut off all our boats and armed ve≈ø≈øels. This obliged me to change my route, that I might not be put betwixt two fires, and at the ≈øame time be able to bring off Colonel Warner, to whom I ≈øent orders, if he found the enemy too ≈øtrong, to retreat to Rutland, where he would find me to cover him, that place lying nearly at an equal di≈øtance from both. After a very fatiguing march of ≈øeven days, in which the army ≈øuffered much from bad weather and want of provi≈øion, I joined General Schuyler the 12th in≈øtant.

It was my original plan to retreat to this place, that I might be betwixt General Burgoyne and the inhabitants, and that the militia might have ≈øomething in this quarter to collect to. It is now effected, and the militia are coming in, ≈øo that I have the mo≈øt ≈øanguine hopes that the progre≈øs of the enemy will be checked, and I may yet have the ≈øatisfaction to experience, that, altho' I have lo≈øt a po≈øt, I have eventually ≈øaved a State.

Perhaps I may be cen≈øured, by tho≈øe who are unacquainted with the ≈øituation I was in, for not ≈øooner calling the militia to my a≈ø≈øi≈øtance. I think I informed Congre≈øs that I could not do that for want of provi≈øion; and as ≈øoon as I got a ≈øupply I did call for them, and was joined by near 900 the day before the evacuation, but they came from home ≈øo ill provided, that they could not, nor did not, propo≈øe to ≈øtay with me but a few days. The two Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts regiments of militia likewi≈øe, which compo≈øed part of the garri≈øon, gave me notice that their time expired in two days, and they intended then to go home. In vain did I beg of their officers to exert every influence they had over them, and, from their ≈øub≈øequent behaviour, I am fully per≈øuaded the officers are mo≈øt to blame. Inclo≈øed is a copy of the Council of War, in which you will find the principles upon which the retreat was undertaken. As I found all the General Officers ≈øo fully of opinion that it ≈øhould be done immediately,

I have the utmo≈øt confidence in the candour of Congre≈øs, and per≈øuade my≈øelf, notwith≈øtanding the lo≈øs they have ≈øu≈øtained, when they have impartially con≈øidered that I was po≈øted, with little more than 2000 men, in a place that required 10,000 to defend it‚Äîthat the≈øe 2000 were ill equipped and wor≈øe armed, not above one bayonet in ten, an arm e≈ø≈øential in the defence of lines‚Äîthat with the≈øe 2000 I have made good a retreat from under the no≈øe of an army at lea≈øt four times their numbers, and have them now betwixt the enemy and the country, ready to act again≈øt them‚Äîthat my conduct will appear at lea≈øt not de≈øerving cen≈øure.

General St. Clair's que≈øtion. Do you recollect the general ≈øtrength of the parties that were ≈øent out?
A. Sometimes a Subaltern's command, ≈øometimes a Captain's command, Captain Whitcomb being out frequently; ≈øometimes by twos and threes, merely as ≈øpies.

General St. Clair's que≈øtion. Would the ≈øending of larger parties have an≈øwered a better purpo≈øe than of ≈øending the parties that were ≈øent, and could larger parties have been ≈øent without great danger of lo≈øing them?

A. For the ≈øake of gaining intelligence of the approach of the enemy, or to a≈øcertain their numbers, could have been much better attained by ≈ømall parties than by large ones, as any con≈øiderable number of men marching in that woody country, where the ground is covered with mo≈øs, might ea≈øily be di≈øcovered, and of con≈øequence would be expo≈øed to have been cut off by the enemy.
General St. Clair's que≈øtion. Do you recollect whether the working parties were increa≈øed on or after the 20th of June?

A. If I remember right, the detail was taken off, and we were ordered to work by brigades, to turn out in the brigade every officer and man who were off duty and able to work, to throw up lines on Mount Independence, and al≈øo to fell the trees on the ≈øides and at the bottom of the hill. Near twenty acres of trees were felled.
General St. Clair's que≈øtion. Was there any wood on Mount Independence, to have ≈øupplied the garri≈øon in ca≈øe of a ≈øiege, or was there a magazine of wood laid in?

A. There was no magazine of wood laid in. There was ≈øome ≈øcattering logs upon the top of the hill, and ≈øo much upon the ≈øides, that I believe we ≈øhould not have been put to any difficulty in getting wood, in ca≈øe we had been be≈øieged.
General St. Clair's que≈øtion. How long do you ≈øuppo≈øe the wood that was on the Mount would have furni≈øhed firing for the garri≈øon we had?
A. At that ≈øea≈øon of the year it might have la≈øted us a fortnight.

General St. Clair's que≈øtion. Could we have ≈øpared men from the works that we were engaged in, to have laid in a further ≈øupply of wood, or had we a number of draught cattle ≈øufficient to have brought it from any di≈øtance?

A. At that time we had not half men enough to man our works. I never under≈øtood we had many teams, but I do not recollect the number. What few teams we had were employed in tran≈øporting the ≈øtores from Lake George Landing to Lake Champlain.
General St. Clair's que≈øtion. Do you recollect, after the enemy landed at Three Mile Point, and before they broke ground, my ordering the men to lie a night or two on their arms?
A. I do.

General St. Clair's que≈øtion. Did you not under≈øtand the rea≈øon of that order was, that tho' I did not think the enemy were in force, yet I thought they might attempt to carry us by a coup-de-main?
A. I don't recollect it.
General St. Clair's que≈øtion. Was our force in any degree adequate to the defence of the places?

A. No; I think that the places could not have been maintained unle≈øs with at lea≈øt 10,000 good troops, and we ought to have had po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of two hills without the French lines, as al≈øo the one on the other ≈øide of the Lake, known by the name of Mount Defiance.

Major General St. Clair produces a paper, and a≈øks General Poor whether the matter therein contained was the order of march and di≈øtribution of batteaus, that was agreed upon at the Council on the 5th of July?‚Äî The paper is as follows:

160 from General Poor's brigade, commanded by Lieut. Col. Read and Major Durborn‚Äî150 from General Patter≈øon's, commanded by Col. Francis‚Äî6 Captains, 12 Subalterns, and non-commi≈ø≈øioned in proportion‚Äîto advance as a picket in the front of the French lines.
ORDER OF MARCH.

General Poor to lead the column with his brigade; General Patter≈øon to follow; Colonel Long; General Fermoy; Robi≈øon to march with his regiment on the left flank; and Colonel Bellows, with Williams's regiment, on the right.
Ho≈øpital, 6 batteaus; Artillery, 20 batteaus; Quarter-Ma≈øter and Engineers, 10 batteaus; Clothier, 4 batteaus; Provi≈øion, 30 batteaus.
A. I very well remember the orders, and I think it to be the paper.
General St. Clair's que≈øtion. Do you recollect a picket to be advanced, con≈øi≈øting of the number of men, and under the officers mentioned in the paper?

A. I well remember it. I was de≈øired by you, when this picket was paraded, to po≈øt them with the other picket, which I think was 150 men, as near the enemy as I could without bringing on an action, and to give them particular orders in the morning, when I was to call them in, that they were to compo≈øe the rear guard, which I did.

General St. Clair's que≈øtion. Did you not under≈øtand that the rea≈øon of ordering out that picket was, to prevent any ≈øurpri≈øe happening to us while the men were employed in carrying the ≈øtores and baggage to the landing place?
A. Yes; and likewi≈øe to form a chain of centinels from water to water, to prevent any of our men de≈øerting to them, and giving them any information.
General St Clair's que≈øtion. Do you recollect the burning of General Fermoy's hou≈øe?

A. Yes; before I called in the pickets on Ticonderoga ≈øide I ≈øaw that hou≈øe in flames, which laid the hill that his brigade was on open to the view of the enemy, as I could ≈øee every movement they were making, ≈øtriking their tents and loading and carrying off their baggage, which induced me to order in the pickets one half an hour ≈øooner than I ≈øhould otherwi≈øe have done, as the principal part of the troops on Ticonderoga ≈øide had cro≈ø≈øed the bridge, in order to embark their baggage on board the boats, the wind being ≈øo high the boats could not be brought over.
General St. Clair's que≈øtion. Were not orders given not to ≈øet fire to any of the buildings?

A. Yes: You gave me particular orders, as ≈øoon as I had po≈øted the pickets, to communicate your orders with re≈øpect to the evacuation of the place to the commanding officers of regiments in my brigade, and de≈øired,
as ≈øoon as the baggage was packed up, that every light, both from fire and from candle, might be put out, previous to ≈øtriking the tents and putting the baggage on board the boats. I under≈øtood the rea≈øon was, to prevent the enemy from making any di≈øcovery of our intentions; and had not the wind been ≈øo very high, which ob≈øtructed the moving of the boats, we ≈øhould have been able to have left the place by two o'clock, as was determined on.
General St. Clair's que≈øtion. Was not the confu≈øion of marching off the troops from Mount Independence occa≈øioned by that hou≈øe of General Fermoy's having been ≈øet on fire?
A. I believe that was the principal occa≈øion of it.
General St. Clair's que≈øtion. How far did the troops march before that confu≈øion was, in a great mea≈øure, remedied?

A. I marched in front. I frequently fell back to the rear of my brigade, to examine into their ≈øituation, and before we had marched many miles I got them nearly all together; I can ≈øay nothing with re≈øpect to the others; and the fir≈øt halt we made the brigades were all formed in order, and marched ≈øo during the whole retreat, excepting Colonel Leonard's and Colonel Wells's, two militia regiments, who behaved with the greate≈øt di≈øorder.
General St. Clair's que≈øtion. Do you recollect of one or both of the≈øe regiments having broke the line of march?

A. The day after the evacuation, when we arrived at Otter Creek, we were alarmed by a report that the enemy were ju≈øt in our rear. I, being in front, was ordered to cro≈øs the bridge, and draw the men up upon the mo≈øt advantageous ground I could find. I po≈øted the regiment that Lieut. Colonel Hale commanded at a ford; he left it, and went off. In the evening, on our march, about a mile and a half from that place, I came up where Colonel Hale was with his regiment. The regiment had four oxen killed and ≈økinned. I a≈øked him how he came there without leave? he ≈øaid he came to get ≈øome provi≈øion, to prevent his men from ≈øtarving. I ordered him to cut up his meat, to be ready to fall into the line of march, which he might be in a few minutes; if not, we ≈øhould march but about a mile and a half, and make a halt. I moved on, and in about ten minutes found his regiment running by my brigade, and he nearly at the head of them. He, with about forty of his men, pa≈ø≈øed the brigade. I rode forward, and halted him till part of one regiment of my brigade had pa≈ø≈øed him; he came up again, and in≈øi≈øted on pa≈ø≈øing, as he would not be left in the rear. I turned out about forty men, and ordered them to fire upon them, unle≈øs they would remain on the ground till the line of march came up, where they were to fall in, which halted them. Both regiments frequently broke the line of march.
General St. Clair's que≈øtion. Do you recollect, whether the troops, at the time of the evacuation, were ordered to take five days provi≈øion with them?
A. They were ordered to take ≈øeveral days provi≈øion with them, which was judged ≈øufficient to have carried them to the North River, had we pur≈øued the route we expected to take.

General St. Clair's que≈øtion. During my command at Ticonderoga, did you di≈øcover any thing that had the appearance of cowardice in me, or induced you to think me treacherous, or inattentive to the progre≈øs of the enemy?

A. I was once with you where you were in danger, and ≈øundry times when we have expected an immediate attack, and never di≈øcovered the lea≈øt di≈øcompo≈øure of mind, but you always appeared with the greate≈øt bravery and ≈øteadine≈øs, becoming the character of an officer. From your clo≈øe application to your duty by day, before the enemy made their appearance at Ticonderoga, and your con≈øtant application both by day and night, after they came there, gave me every rea≈øon to imagine you left nothing undone that was in your power to contribute to the ≈øtrength of the garri≈øon; therefore I had not the lea≈øt rea≈øon to induce me to think you either treacherous or neglectful of your duty, I remember your ob≈øerving to me, if I evacuate the place, my character will be ruined; if I remain here, the army will be lo≈øt; but I am determined to evacuate it, altho' it will give ≈øuch an alarm that has not happened in the country ≈øince the war commenced.
General St. Clair's que≈øtion. At what time did this conver≈øation happen. Was it previous to the re≈øolution that was entered into by the Council of War, or po≈øterior to it?

A. It was after it. You gave your rea≈øons for it, and ≈øaid that it was to throw this body of troops between the country and Burgoyne, that the militia might have a body to collect to; which, if this body was cut off, they would have none, and of cour≈øe Burgoyne would pur≈øue his operations without any ob≈øtacle, or words to that effect.
General St. Clair's que≈øtion. Were you with me at Trenton or Princeton, and what was my conduct at tho≈øe places with re≈øpect to courage?
A. I was with you at both places. We were not brought to clo≈øe action at either place, but you behaved with the greate≈øt ≈øpirit, and with as much coolne≈øs as at any other time.
Q. Court. At what time did General St. Clair receive the fir≈øt compleat intelligence of the ≈øtrength and de≈øigns of the enemy?

A. I don't recollect any that was obtained before the pri≈øoner was taken; he was the fir≈øt per≈øon that gave us intelligence who commanded the enemy's army, of their ≈øtrength and de≈øigns, and that not until the next day after he was taken.
Q. Court. Was there any other intelligence received, between the time of the pri≈øoners being taken and the time of the evacuation?
A. There was a report in camp, that ≈øome of the inhabitants ≈øaid they were clearing a road through the wood to get into our rear. The Jagers al≈øo mentioned that they were clearing a road.

Q. Court. Do you know whether it was a prevailing opinion, that nothing ≈øerious would be attempted again≈øt Ticonderoga that campaign, and whether it was not expected that the enemy's troops would have been ≈øent round from Quebec to the ≈øouthern army?

A. A little before General St. Clair arrived at Ticonderoga the enemy made a movement up the Lake, with a number of boats and one or two ve≈ø≈øels, tarried a few days, and returned. I acquainted General Gates of it, and further acquainted him that I was informed they were making preparations at St. John's to proceed with their whole army. He wrote me, that he had the ≈øtronge≈øt a≈ø≈øurances from Congre≈øs that the King's
troops were all ordered round to New-York, leaving only a ≈øufficient number to garri≈øon their forts, and de≈øire≈øt me to be getting every thing in readine≈øs, that if the enemy went out of one door, we mu≈øt enter the other. He farther mentioned in his letter, that we might daily expect alarms, as they commanded the Lake, and might come up with their ≈øhipping, and that the intelligence he had by a ≈øpy that came from Canada corroborated the ≈øentiment of Congre≈øs.
Q. Court. What orders had the commanding officer of the rear guard, and did he obey the orders he received?

A. He was ordered upon his coming in to ≈øweep every thing off the ground upon Ticonderoga ≈øide, to bring every man and bea≈øt, which I under≈øtood he effected, and then to fall in the rear of General Fermoy's brigade, as a rear guard to the army.
Q. Court. What orders did the officer of the rear guard receive at Hubbarton?

A. The fir≈øt halt that was propo≈øed to be made was at Lacey's camp, which was the fir≈øt cleared land we came to after we left Mount Independence. When I got within about a mile of the place, I met an inhabitant, who informed me there was a large number of the enemy and Indians at Hubbarton, which was two miles farther, which induced me to continue the march until I arrived at Burnam's, in Hubbarton, where it was ≈øaid the enemy were. Upon our arrival we were told that about 500 of the enemy had been there, and had gone to Ca≈øtle-Town. There I marked out the ground for each brigade, po≈øted officers to fall in with his brigade and regiment as they came up. We had then made a march of about twenty miles, which had fatigued many of our feeble men; ≈øo that the officer commanding of the rear guard thought proper to halt at the place fir≈øt propo≈øed, Lacey's camp, two miles in our rear. General St. Clair ≈øent ≈øeveral times to order the rear guard up; the la≈øt me≈ø≈øenger came and ≈øaid they were on their way up. As we tarried there about three or four hours, General St. Clair ≈øaid he would march to Ca≈øtle-Town with his army, and would leave Colonel Hale's and Warner's regiments to cover his retreat, with orders for them to move on moderately. Some time in the evening I heard the General expre≈øs a good deal of unea≈øine≈øs and concern that Colonel Francis did not come up with the rear. Towards morning he ≈øent one of his Aids up to order them down immediately; and, if I mi≈øtake not, ≈øent a ≈øecond time. They did not join the army, but remained until they were attacked by the enemy the next morning.
General St. Clair's que≈øtion. Do you know whether the rear guard had orders to move on to Ca≈øtle-Town that night?
A. I cannot ≈øay po≈øitively that they had, but I under≈øtood they had.

General St. Clair's que≈øtion. Do you recollect my having ≈øent orders to Colonel Pellows and Colonel Halcott's militia regiments, who were halted two miles from Hubbarton, to march up and ≈øupport them upon being attacked?
A. Yes.
General St. Clair's que≈øtion. Was that order obeyed?
A. It was not. The regiments came directly to us at Ca≈øtle-Town.

Major General St. Clair produces a map of Ticonderoga, Mount Independence and the adjacent country, with references, which Colonel Ko≈øeiu≈øzko, on his oath, ≈øays is a true one, to the be≈øt of his knowledge and judgment, except as to the di≈øtances, it not having been made from actual ≈øurvey, but taken from view.

div.p: THE Court met according to adjournment.
Captain Woolcott being ≈øworn,
General St. Clair's que≈øtion. Do you recollect the orders that were given to Colonel Warner at Hubbarton?

A. I was in front when we arrived at Hubbarton, laid down, and got a ≈øleep. When I waked, I found the party were nearly all gone. I a≈øked Captain Smith where they were gone to, who ≈øaid to Ca≈øtle-Town; and having a≈øked him whether we were to march, he ≈øaid it was General St. Clair's orders, delivered by General Patter≈øon, that we were to march to Ca≈øtle-Town. I went into the hou≈øe where Col. Warner, Col. Francis and Col. Hale were, and having a≈øked Col. Warner whether he determined to march any farther, he ≈øaid he did not that night; tho' there were orders to march to Ca≈øtle-Town, he did not intend to go on any farther, becau≈øe the men were much fatigued.
Q. Court. What time did the rear guard arrive at Hubbarton?
A. I believe it was about three or four o'clock in the afternoon.
Q. Court. What time did they leave it the next morning?
A. They commenced their march about eight o'clock, but before the whole got in motion they were attacked by the enemy.
Q. Was Colonel Warner the commanding officer of the rear guard at the time?
A. He was.

Colonel Baldwin, being ≈øworn, ≈øays, On the 5th of July, 1777, about nine o'clock in the evening, General St. Clair ≈øent for me, and told me that he had determined to abandon the place that night; he would have me with the artificers, get all the intrenching tools, and the carpenters and ≈ømiths tools on board of batteaus that were a≈ø≈øigned me for that purpo≈øe, and be ready by two o'clock in the morning to leave the place. I left him and went to my men, got every thing on board belonging to my department agreeable to order, on Ticonderoga
≈øide, by twelve o'clock. I then went to the ≈øtone redoubt, and a≈øked Captain Win≈ølow if he wanted any a≈ø≈øi≈øtance? He told me that every thing was out of the magazine and on board the boats, there was nothing left but his tents, that were to be carried. I then went to Head-Quarters, and was informed that General St. Clair was gone over to the Mount. I rode over, and met him near the fort, told him what I had done, and a≈øked him if he had any further orders? He ≈øaid that the people were all a≈øleep on this ≈øide, wi≈øhed that I would go and wake General Fermoy. I went, called him up, and returned. General St. Clair then de≈øired I would go, and ≈øee to get the ≈øtores away from the magazine that was not then open. I ≈øoon got a large party of men, went to the magazine, and rolled the barrels from it to the landing (I believe about 100 large barrels of powder.) I then went to the landing, where I found the men in great confu≈øion, contending about boats. The wind was high, and it was bad loading them; the men very cro≈øs, and hard to be prevailed with to do their duty. About ≈øun-ri≈øe the army was pa≈øt and the boats put off. There remained only a few barrels of powder and rum, with a ≈ømall matter of baggage on ≈øhore, and there were only two batteaus that lay at a little di≈øtance. I promi≈øed Captain Nicholls, that if he could get the≈øe boats with his carpenters, and carry off what remained at the landing, I would give him a barrel of the rum when he got to Skeen≈øborough; he immediately brought them in, got all on board (except about eight old tents that were not worth carrying, and a howitzer that we run into the Lake and left, with ≈øome carriages for cannon and General St. Clair's waggon) ju≈øt as the enemy came into the works on the hill and fired upon us. The boats pu≈øhed off, and I rode away with Captain Buckland. We ≈øaw none of our people (except General St. Clair's waggoner with his hor≈øes; Captain Buckland rode one of them, and we brought off the other) until we came to the la≈øt hou≈øe; there we found four ≈øoldiers partly drunk. We made them run until we ≈øoon came up with others that were too heavy loaded, and who had ≈øtopped to throw away a part. We endeavoured to bring all up with us, until we came to Colonel Francis, which was about two miles, as near as I can gue≈øs. He had then fell ≈øome ≈ømall di≈øtance in the rear, by rea≈øon of people ≈øtopping to lighten their packs. I marched ≈øome time with him, but he found the front marched too fa≈øt for him. He de≈øired I would ride forward to the General, and de≈øire him to make a ≈ømall halt till he could come up, which was done. We marched to Hubbarton, where the front halted two or three hours. We were informed that a large body of the enemy was ju≈øt gone from the place where we halted as the front came up, and were gone towards Ca≈øtle-Town. After the army had refre≈øhed them≈øelves the General ordered Colonel Warner, with ≈øome others, to wait until Colonel Francis came up with the rear guard, and then march on with them; and then General St. Clair marched with the army to Ca≈øtle-Town, and took twenty-≈øix pri≈øoners on the way‚Äîthere halted for that night, the men very much fatigued. On the morning of the ≈øeventh the rear, with Colonel Warner and Colonel Francis, was attacked at Hubbarton; we heard the guns. General St. Clair immediately ≈øent one of his Aids to order Colonel Bellows, with two militia regiments (that lay two miles on the road towards the rear) to reinforce Colonel Francis, and cover his retreat if it was nece≈ø≈øary; but tho≈øe regiments ≈øoon came down to us, and I heard the Aid ≈øay that he could not by any means prevail with the men to obey the order, and Colonel Bellows did all in his power to get the men to go with him to meet the enemy. The General this morning heard our boats were cut off at Skeen≈øborough, which cau≈øed him to alter his route, and go by the way of Rutland.
General St. Clair's que≈øtion. Do you recollect whether the working parties at Ticonderoga and Mount Independence were increa≈øed or decrea≈øed on or about the 23d day of June, 1777?

A. They were con≈øiderably increa≈øed. There were ≈øeveral works that were not fini≈øhed that were ordered to be done, be≈øides a number of new ones laid out that the men were ordered to work upon, and we continued at the≈øe works both at Mount Independence and Ticonderoga until the day we came away, be≈øides a con≈øiderable reinforcement to the party at work upon the bridge. As the troops increa≈øed the working parties increa≈øed, we having almo≈øt every man upon the ground on duty of one kind or another. There was a regiment of militia con≈øtantly on duty in the woods, under my direction, providing timber for the bridge, that was not included in the details. I had about 100 men, be≈øides the militia on duty with me there, that were not included in the details. I had about 30 out of the militia al≈øo making ≈øhingles, and a party making brick, not included in the details.
General St. Clair's que≈øtion. Was the boom that was laid below the bridge in the Lake fixed in ≈øuch a manner, that it would have been able to have re≈øi≈øted the ≈øhock of a ve≈ø≈øel?
A. The anchors were chiefly lo≈øt from it, the cables having been broken by the ice. I rather think it would not have ≈øtopped their heavy ve≈ø≈øels, though it might their ≈ømaller ones.
General St. Clair's que≈øtion. Did you receive directions for building a general ho≈øpital at Ticonderoga, and were you not employed on that work?

A. I did, from General Schuyler. I was at work on it about the 23d of June, and the greater part of the fatigue-men were then taken from that work to be put on other works. Some of the artificers were taken off, though the greater part of them continued at work on it.
General St. Clair's que≈øtion. What di≈øtance is the la≈øt hou≈øe you have mentioned from Mount Independence?
A. I believe not more than a quarter of a mile from the landing upon the ≈øouth ≈øide of the Mount.
Captain Win≈ølow being ≈øworn.
General St. Clair's que≈øtion. What part of the artillery, and at what po≈øt, did you command at Ticonderoga?
A. I commanded in a ≈øtone redoubt, where there were thirteen pieces of artillery.
General St. Clair's que≈øtion. Were the artillery and ≈øtores that were in that redoubt removed at the time of the evacuation.?

A. The ≈øtores were all removed, and ≈øix of the pieces of artillery. I loaded the cannon in a flat bottomed boat that was given me to load them in, and was ordered, I think by General Poor, afterwards to take them out to put the baggage in. There were al≈øo 40 barrels of powder there, which, with the ≈øtores, I loaded my≈øelf in the boats to go to Skeen≈øborough, after I had got tho≈øe articles down. I was then ordered by General St. Clair, as I was coming up from the boats, to ≈øpike up the remainder of the cannon, to go to the old fort to a≈ø≈øi≈øt in removing the ≈øtores from thence.
General St. Clair's que≈øtion. Were the ≈øtores generally removed from the old fort?
A. Every thing of any con≈øequence was. They were all carried down to the boats at lea≈øt, if they were not put on board.
General St. Clair's que≈øtion. Were the cannon all ≈øpiked that were left?
A. I ≈øpiked all that I had the care of, and ≈øome more that were at the ≈øhore that were brought from the French lines, that could not be embarked.
General St. Clair's que≈øtion. Were you Payma≈øter to the troops at Ticonderoga?
A. I was.
General St. Clair's que≈øtion. Was the military che≈øt ≈øaved?
A. It was. I ≈øent it away the morning of the evacuation, about three o'clock, with four of my men. You ordered me to ≈øend it away ≈øooner, but I could not get a boat to do it.
Q. Did the ≈øtores that were ≈øent from Ticonderoga and Mount Independence, at the time of the evacuation, fall into the hands of the enemy afterwards?
A. They did, after they arrived at Skeen≈øborough; though there might have been ≈øome boats that fell into their hands before they got up to Skeen≈øborough.
Q. To Colonel Hay. Did the ≈øtores that were ≈øent from Ticonderoga and Mount Independence, at the time of the evacuation, fall into the hands of the enemy afterwards?
A. They did at Skeen≈øborough, after an engagement between the enemy's ve≈ø≈øels and ours.
General St. Clair's que≈øtion to Col. Hay. Was not a great part of them de≈øtroyed by fire by our people?
A. One of the ve≈ø≈øels was blown up.
General St. Clair's que≈øtion to Col. Hay. Do you recollect the number of batteaus that were at Ticonderoga, fit for ≈øervice?
A. Not po≈øitively, but I imagine they were about 70
General St. Clair's que≈øtion to Col. Hay. Was the boom below the bridge ≈øo ≈øecured, that it could re≈øi≈øt the ≈øhock of a ve≈ø≈øel?

A. It was ≈øecured with several anchors and cables. It would have ≈øtopped a ve≈ø≈øel's way, ≈øo far as to have expo≈øed her to the fire from on both ≈øides, and made it difficult for her to get back again; but if a ve≈ø≈øel came again≈øt it with a full wind, I never thought it would have re≈øi≈øted her.
General St. Clair's que≈øtion to Col. Hay. Was the wind fair the night of the evacuation for ve≈ø≈øels to come up again≈øt it?
A. It was, and blowed very hard.
General St. Clair's que≈øtion to Col. Hay. If the enemy had attempted it that night, was it not probable they would have broke through every ob≈øtruction?

A. I am of opinion they would have carried away our boom and broke our floating bridge, but mu≈øt probably, by that means, have been thrown athwart ≈øome of the caffoons, and thereby expo≈øed to the fire of our batteries on both ≈øides, until the cannon were removed or ≈øpiked up.
Lieutenant Colonel Stevens being ≈øworn,
General St. Clair's que≈øtion. Did you command the artillery at Ticonderoga at the time of the evacuation?
A. I did.
General St. Clair's que≈øtion. Do you recollect what orders were given to you at the time of the evacuation?

A. About ≈øeven o'clock in the evening of the 5th of July was the fir≈øt of my hearing of the intended evacuation. You waited on me at my quarters (as I was unwell) and informed me that the retreat was to take place that night. On the information, I told you I had rea≈øon to cur≈øe the day I ever put my feet into the country, there being ≈øo much retreating. Yoy ≈øaid that you had the greate≈øt rea≈øon to cur≈øe the day, and intimated that more blame would fall on you than on me for lo≈øing the artillery. You then advi≈øed with me what artillery to bring off, and was anxious for bringing the whole off, and offered me what a≈ø≈øi≈øtance I wanted. I told you it was impo≈ø≈øible to bring the whole off, on account of the deficiency of boats; and 500 men were turned out to my a≈ø≈øi≈øtance. You had agreed to move all the pieces except the eighteen pounders, and tho≈øe above them, which I got to the landing, but the ≈øcarcity of boats was the occa≈øion of my leaving ≈øome of them there. I did make out to get a number of them to Skeen≈øborough, but they were lo≈øt there. I ≈øhould have got the whole there, had not the boats been taken up by General Poor for the men's baggage, into which the pieces were to go. The boats with the ammunition and powder had reached almo≈øt to Skeen≈øborough before the enemy came up with them. One of them we ≈øet fire to, with fifteen tons of powder, which blew up; the re≈øt fell into the hands of the enemy.
General St. Clair's que≈øtion. Were not orders given to ≈øpike up all the cannon tha could not be removed?
A. There were.
General St. Clair's que≈øtion. Was that done?
A. It was. You advi≈øed with me about knocking the trunnions off, but being fearful it would make too much noi≈øe and alarm the enemy, as they were ≈øo near, it was omitted.
General St. Clair's que≈øtion. Was there any artillery ordered to be fired that night, to amu≈øe the enemy?

A. There were two eighteen pounders in the Jer≈øey battery fired every ≈øeven minutes at their ≈øhipping, and at a battery that the enemy were rai≈øing oppo≈øite to the Jer≈øey battery, which continued till near ≈øun-ri≈øe the next morning, to amu≈øe them.
General St. Clair's que≈øtion. At the time the enemy moved up with their gun boats, as if they meant to attack the Jer≈øey battery, do you recollect what pa≈ø≈øed at the time between you and me?
A. You ≈øeemed to be angry at me for firing without your po≈øitive orders, and ≈øaid you would rather give fifty pounds than I ≈øhould have fired.
General St. Clair's que≈øtion. Do you recollect my explaining to you the rea≈øon of my ≈øaying ≈øo?

A. I do not recollect your explaining to me the rea≈øon. You expre≈ø≈øed in your di≈øcour≈øe to me, that you wi≈øhed they would come nearer, that we might have a fairer chance to ≈øink them; and I judged that it was on account of your thinking they were not near enough.
General St. Clair's que≈øtion. Did you receive any orders for di≈ømounting and moving the cannon at Ticonderoga?

A. I did about the latter end of June, or beginning of July, from General Schuyler, and moved all the
cannon above a twelve pounder, except the two eighteen pounders which were left at the Jer≈øey battery, to Mount Independence, and laid them on ≈økids, with their vents down, which induced the ≈øoldiers to think that a retreat was intended from Ticonderoga to Mount Independence. I moved al≈øo the ammunition by your orders, except about one hundred rounds, to Mount Independence.
General St. Clair's que≈øtion. Was all the fixed ammunition removed at the time of the evacuation?
A. I have the greate≈øt rea≈øon to think that all was brought off.
General St. Clair's que≈øtion. Was there any annoyance given by the artillery to the enemy in their approaches to the place?
A. They were fired upon from the French lines, and from every quarter where they made their appearance, by heavy artillery, from the fir≈øt of their approach to the evacuation.
Mr. Boyer being ≈øworn, General St. Clair's que≈øtion. In what ≈øtation did you act at Ticonderoga?
A. As an A≈ø≈øi≈øtant Commi≈ø≈øary of Provi≈øion.
General St. Clair's que≈øtion. When I called on you on the 5th of July for a return of provi≈øion, what quantity did you report to me to be on hand?
A. I imagine there were two thou≈øand barrels of flour, and eight hundred barrels of beef and pork, the greater part was pork, and it was about that quantity I reported to you there was.
General St. Clair's que≈øtion. Do you recollect what quantity of provi≈øion was i≈ø≈øued as a ration at Ticonderoga?

A. I think, but am not po≈øitive, there was i≈ø≈øued for a ration, one pound of bread, one pound of beef, or three quarters of a pound of pork in lieu of beef. That was all they daily drew. The other parts of a ration I do not remember.
General St. Clair's que≈øtion. Was there any allowance made to the men for the ≈ømall articles you could not furni≈øh them with?
A. They had briefs given them for them.
General St. Clair's que≈øtion. How long were you A≈ø≈øi≈øtant Commi≈ø≈øary at that place?
A. About ≈øix weeks.
General St. Clair's que≈øtion. Had you received any directions from any of the principals in the department, what quantity of provi≈øion to i≈ø≈øue as a daily ration?
A. I do not remember that I had.
General St. Clair's que≈øtion. Did you not i≈ø≈øue the ≈øame ration that had been i≈ø≈øued before you came into office?
A. I i≈ø≈øued the ≈øame quantity that had been i≈ø≈øued before I came into the office.
