body.p:
I INFORMED you ye≈øterday that an encampment of the enemy had been di≈øcovered at Gilliland's Creek. I a≈øt night two of their ve≈ø≈øels came up to Crown Point, and this morning there are ≈øeven lying at that place; the re≈øt of their fleet is probably but a little lower down, as we heard their morning guns di≈øtinctly at different places. They have al≈øo debarked ≈øome troops, and encamped upon Chimney Point. Whether
they have landed at Crown Point my ≈øcout-boat did not di≈øcover, not daring to venture far enough down the Lake for that purpo≈øe, on account of their ≈øhipping; but I have ≈øent a party on this ≈øide the river, which, I doubt not, will bring a ju≈øt account of their ≈øituation.

I cannot help repeating to you the di≈øagreeable ≈øituation we are in, nor can I ≈øee the lea≈øt pro≈øpect of our being able to defend the po≈øts, unle≈øs the militia come in; and ≈øhould the enemy protract their operations, or inve≈øt us, and content them≈øelves with a ≈øimple blockade, we are infallibly ruined. I have thoughts of calling for the Berk≈øhire militia, which are neare≈øt to us, and will probably be the mo≈øt alert to come to our a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, becau≈øe they are in ≈øome mea≈øure covered by this po≈øt; but on that I ≈øhall con≈øult the other General Officers. This, however, is clear to me, that we ≈øhall be obliged to abandon this ≈øide, and then they will ≈øoon force the other from us; nor do I ≈øee that a retreat will in any ≈øhape be practicable. Every thing, however, ≈øhall be done, that is po≈ø≈øible, to fru≈øtrate the de≈øigns of the enemy; but what can be expected from troops ill armed, naked and unaccoutred. I ≈øhall write you again as ≈øoon as the ≈øcout returns,

closer.signed: And am, dear General, &c. A. ST. CLAIR.

body.p: THIS moment I have received information from Hoite, of Otter Creek, that a large party of Indians and Tories are gone up that creek, ≈øuppo≈øed to be five hundred, and are de≈øigned to cut off the communication by Skeen≈øborough. They took a pair of oxen from one of the inhabitants, and drove them to about two miles above Middlebury Falls, where they halted the day before ye≈øterday, and killed and dre≈ø≈øed the cattle; and it is ≈øuppo≈øed that to-night they will be at the new road near Ca≈øtle-Town, which is twenty-eight miles from hence, and twelve or fourteen from Skeen≈øborough. They reported that a very large party were gone on the we≈øt ≈øide of the Lake, to fall on Fort George. That is ≈øaid to con≈øi≈øt of 1000 Indians and Canadians.

We have al≈øo had ju≈øt now another attack at the mills; we have two men killed, two taken, and two wounded, one mortally. The ≈øcene thickens fa≈øt, and Sunday next, it ≈øeems, is fixed for the attack on this place. We mu≈øt make the be≈øt we can of it, and I hope at lea≈øt to cripple them ≈øo as they may not be able to pur≈øue their fortune, ≈øhould it declare in their favour.

I ≈øent a party down la≈øt night to reconnoitre them, who are not yet returned, which gives me ≈øome unea≈øine≈øs. I hope, however, they are ≈øafe, and will bring me ≈øome intelligence of con≈øequence. I have ≈øome thoughts, if they are not numerous, of attacking them. If they get the wor≈øt, it will oblige them to recal their parties. If not, there will be too many ≈øtill left, to become pri≈øoners.
I have ≈øent to the Grants to inform them of the Otter Creek party, and to de≈øire that all they can po≈ø≈øibly ≈øpare of the militia may be ready to march at a minute's warning.

closer.signed: I am, dear General, Your's, &c. A. ST. CLAIR.

div.p: Major General Schuyler being ≈øworn,
General St. Clair's que≈øtion. What troops had you e≈øtimated for the defence of the garri≈øons of Ticonderoga and Mount Independence?

A. Ten thou≈øand continental troops. I do not know that I mentioned in my letter to General Wa≈øhington and to Congre≈øs that they ≈øhould be continental troops, but I intended them to have been continental troops.
General St. Clair's que≈øtion. Did you think the po≈øts tenable with the force I had?

In an≈øwer to this que≈øtion, General Schuyler produces an extract from a copy of a letter to Congre≈øs, dated the 8th of June. 1777, which he ≈øays was ≈øent by expre≈øs to Congre≈øs, and was received by them about the 13th of June, but he did not receive any an≈øwer to the letter till late in July. The extract is as follows:
Extract of a Letter from Major General Schuyler to the Honourable the Continental Congre≈øs.
Albany,
June 8, 1777.
SIR,
I DO my≈øelf the honour to advi≈øe you that I arrived here on Tue≈øday, the 3d in≈øtant, and found an account, which I received on my way up, that the enemy were approaching Ticonderoga, to be without foundation.
I inclo≈øe you, Sir, a return of the troops at Ticonderoga and this place. As ≈øoon as I procure tho≈øe from the other po≈øts, I ≈øhall make out a general return, and do my≈øelf the honour to tran≈ømit copies to you and his Excellency General Wa≈øhington.
You will perceive, by the return of the Commi≈ø≈øary of Provi≈øion, which I al≈øo inclo≈øe, that only 337 barrels of provi≈øion, of the meat kind, have been forwarded to Ticonderoga ≈øince the 26th of March, and no fre≈øh beef; ≈øo that the ≈øtock of ≈øalted provi≈øion ≈øince that time is con≈øiderably dimini≈øhed, nor is there any con≈øiderable quantity provided in the country. I have, therefore, directed the Commi≈ø≈øary to forward an immediate ≈øupply of fre≈øh beef, that as much of the ≈øalted beef and pork may be ≈øaved as po≈ø≈øible, in order to have a ≈øtock on hand, in ca≈øe the enemy ≈øhould be able ≈øo to interrupt the communication, as to prevent cattle being ≈øent on.
Inclo≈øe you copy of the in≈øtructions I have given General St. Clair: I have directed that Mount Independence ≈øhould be the primary object, of attention.
Fir≈øt. Becau≈øe, if the lines on the we≈øt ≈øide ≈øhould be perfectly compleated, it will not be in our power to man them properly with the whole force de≈øtined for this department, if it could be all collected at Ticonderoga, which it cannot; for the ≈øeveral po≈øts on the Mohawk river, and tho≈øe on the communication between this and Ticonderoga, will take at lea≈øt 2000 men. I have in view the drawing part of the army to this ≈øide of the Lake.
Second. Becau≈øe I think it rather imprudent that the greater part of our army ≈øhould occupy a po≈øt, which, if the enemy ≈øhould be able ≈øo to inve≈øt, as to cut off the communication with the country on this ≈øide, we might po≈ø≈øibly experience a di≈øa≈øter ≈øimilar to that at Fort Wa≈øhington.
Third. I am fully convinced that between 2 and 3000 men can effectually maintain Mount Independence, and ≈øecure the pa≈øs.
Fourth. If the whole army was at Mount Independence, it is po≈ø≈øible that a want of provi≈øion might oblige us to abandon that important po≈øt.
Fifth. If the enemy ≈øhould attempt to draw their boats over land into Lake George from beyond the Three Mile Point, our naval ≈øtrength on Lake George will prevent their progre≈øs: If it did not, we ≈øhall have a body of troops to oppo≈øe them with.
Sixth. Becau≈øe, if Mount Independence ≈øhould be inve≈øted, the militia will readily join when they have an army to join, and the ≈øeige may be rai≈øed.
Seventh. Becau≈øe, if they ≈øhould attempt to march a body of troops from Crown Point, leaving Ticonderoga on their left (by the road la≈øt year cut by the tories who joined General Carlton) to interrupt the communication, there will be a force to meet them, and to prevent the evil con≈øequences of ≈øuch a manoeuvre of their's.
Eighth. Becau≈øe, if a ≈øudden irruption ≈øhould be made on the Mohawk River, or from New-York by Hud≈øon's River, a force will be at hand to face them. Be≈øides the≈øe con≈øiderations, there are oeconomical ones al≈øo to induce me to this di≈øpo≈øition of the army, if it can be done without injury, which I am fully of opinion it may, and will certainly be ≈øo, if General Carlton ≈øent part of the troops, from Canada to New-York or ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ where.
I have mentioned the matter to General St. Clair, and although I did not adduce to him all the rea≈øons given above, yet he is in ≈øentiment with me on the ≈øubject. May I be permitted to intreat the direction of Congre≈øs.
PHILIP SCHUYLER. [True Copy.]

General Schuyler ≈øays further, in an≈øwer to the que≈øtion, that when he mentioned in the letter to Congre≈øs that between two and three thou≈øand men were ≈øufficient to have maintained Mount Independence, he conceived the ‚Ä¢ ort, about which orders had been given the beginning of February to Colonel Baldwin, was far advanced; that the ob≈øtruction in the Lake was compleated; that there were carriages provided for the cannon; that the lines were compleated, and not by one half ≈øo exten≈øive as he found them.
General St. Clair's que≈øtion. Did you ever give me any orders for evacuating the≈øe garri≈øons?

A. No. The rea≈øon why I did not give you any orders for evacuating the≈øe garri≈øons was, becau≈øe I had wrote this letter to Congre≈øs, and they did not give me any orders about it; and as the continent conceived them of great importance, and very ≈øtrong, I did not think my≈øelf at liberty to give any orders for an evacuation of them.

General St. Clair's que≈øtion. Was the defective ≈øtate in which you found the works at Ticonderoga and Mount Independence owing to any negligence in me, or di≈øregard to the orders I received from you?

A. It could not be owing to any negligence in you, or di≈øregard to the orders you received from me, as you had arrived there but a few days before; not was it owing to the negligence of any officer who had commanded there in the winter or ≈øpring before; nor to the commanding officer of the artiliery or the engineer. I conceive it to be owing to a want of men and a want of materials.
General St. Clair's que≈øtion. Do you know of any ≈øteps taken by the ea≈øtern ≈øtates to reinforce the≈øe po≈øts, after their inve≈øtiture?

A. Immediately on my return from Ticonderoga, I wrote to the ea≈øtern ≈øtates to ha≈øten on the remainder of the continental troops. Some troops came up in con≈øequence of my application, but did not reach Albany till ≈øome time after the evacuation of Ticonderoga. Upon receiving the fir≈øt letter from you after I returned from Ticonderoga, I applied to the ea≈øtern ≈øtates, and to this, for reinforcements of militia. The militia from the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts arrived at Fort-Edward, I believe, between the 4th and 7th of July. A few from Connecticut did not join us until towards the latter end of July. Tho≈øe from this ≈øtate got up much about the ≈øame time that the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts did. The Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts militia were up as ≈øoon at Fort-Edward, and tho≈øe from this ≈øtate, as I could rea≈øonably expect them to be. Connecticut, as I was informed by Governor Trumbull, had a call for the militia from General Wa≈øhington, to go to the Highland, or Peeks-Kill. That was the rea≈øon that their militia did not join us ≈øooner.
General St. Clair's que≈øtion. Did the force you had collected, ≈øuppo≈øing the garri≈øons to have held out, put you in a ≈øituation to have rai≈øed the ≈øiege?

A. I believe that, with all the troops you brought with you, with the reinforcement with General Nixon, and including all the militia, I had not at Fort-Edward, about the 20th of July, more than five thou≈øand men. If the garri≈øon had remained, I ≈øhould have had no more than three thou≈øand militia, before I was joined by General Nixon, to have marched to its relief, which number I conceive very inadequate to have rai≈øed the ≈øiege. General Nixon, I believe, arrived about the 12th or 13th of July; but if I had had a force which I might think was ≈øufficient, yet I ≈øhould not have been able to have rai≈øed the ≈øiege for want of provi≈øion, there being ≈øcarcely any provi≈øion of the meat kind in the department; flour was plenty. Nor was there any ≈øtock of provi≈øion of the meat kind laid in, not even a ≈øufficiency of ≈øalted meat to have furni≈øhed the ≈øcouts with. We had not lead in the department ≈øufficient for an army any thing like to have rai≈øed the ≈øiege with. At Fort-Edward, on the 7th of July, we were obliged to ≈øtrip the men that were there of every cartridge they had, to ≈øend them to Fort-Ann, and were left without any lead for ≈øome days, excepting a mere trifle I got from Albany, a very ≈ømall quantity brought up by the militia, and by ≈øtripping the windows.
General St. Clair's que≈øtion. Do you know the u≈øual weight of a barrel of beef or pork in that country?

A. Barrels of beef or pork ≈øhould weigh, when they are well packed, about 200 weight; but I have frequently complained that the barrels of beef or pork of the Commi≈ø≈øary's were not in well packed as they ought to be, owing to their making u≈øe of ≈øoldiers and others, whom I ≈øuppo≈øed did not under≈øtand the bu≈øine≈øs ≈øo well, ≈øo that the barrels were but ≈ølighty packed. I have ≈øeen ≈øome that I ≈øuppo≈øe a quarter of meat might have been put in more, others that the deficiency was le≈øs. I ≈øhould imagine, if the re≈øt of the barrels were the ≈øame as tho≈øe I in≈øpected into, they would not have averaged more than 170 pounds each.

General St. Clair's que≈øtion. Did I not, when it was determined in the Council of Officers that was held the 20th of June, 1777, re≈øpecting the holding Mount Independence and evacuating Ticonderoga, expre≈øs my opinion that it would be impo≈ø≈øible to hold that po≈øt, when the other ≈øide of the Lake ≈øhould be abandoned?
A. I remember perfectly well you did.
Colonel Scammell being ≈øworn,
General St. Clair's que≈øtion. Do you know any in≈øtance of cowardice, treachery, or inattention to the progre≈øs of the enemy, that I was guilty of during my command at Ticonderoga?

Major General St. Clair admits, that in the number of men returned on command the 28th of June, there were about 457 on command in the garri≈øon.

Major Dunn, Aid de Camp to General St. Clair, being ≈øworn, ≈øays:

I arrived at Ticonderoga about the 18th of June, 1777. A day or two after my arrival I went round the lines on Ticonderoga, and found them much in the ≈øame ≈øituation as they were in November, 1776, excepting the redoubts on the low ground, which were evacuated, and a chain of new ones erected on the height between the old ≈øort and the right of the French lines. The≈øe were nearly compleated. In ≈øome cannon were mounted, and a party of fatigue at work on the re≈øt. On Mount Independence I found a party of about 100 men, under the direction of Colonel Ko≈øeiu≈øzko, erecting three redoubts in the rear of the Mount, and forming an abbatis, the old one having taken fire ≈øome time before, and was chiefly de≈øtroyed. One other party of about 150 men, under Colonel Baldwin, ≈øinking a number of piers in the pa≈ø≈øage between the two po≈øts. One other fatigue party, employed daily in bringing ≈øtores and provi≈øion from Lake George Landing. Be≈øides the≈øe, Colonel Hay, the Quarter-Ma≈øter General, had a party of Negroes, taken from the different regiments, as a con≈øtant fatigue, independent of the daily detail. There were two regiments of militia cutting logs for the piers then ≈øinking, the≈øe were likewi≈øe independent of the daily detail, and exempt from all other garri≈øon duty. All the≈øe parties of fatigue were continued as above, with very little alteration, till the evacuation took place. Being the only Aid de Camp belonging to General St Clair's family, mo≈øt of the orders delivered were through me, and therefore I had the greate≈øt opportunities of ≈øeeing all parties that were ≈øent out; and after my arrival, I do not remember a day that parties were not ≈øent out on the ea≈øt or we≈øt, and frequently on both ≈øides of the Lake Champlain, to reconnoitre the Lake and woods. Tho≈øe parties con≈øi≈øted from 15 to 50 men. I do not recollect exactly the time the enemy fir≈øt made their appearance on the Lake, but remember perfectly, after their appearing with their fleet at Split-Rock, that no party could be per≈øwaded (becau≈øe of the ≈øavages) to approach near enough to di≈øcover any thing of con≈øequence. They frequently fell in with the enemy's parties, but were always obliged to retire. In this ≈øtate we remained till the enemy landed on Three Mile Point, I think on the 30th of June; and on this occa≈øion I heard the General complain that his garri≈øon was not in force to ri≈øque a party large enough to do them any damage. This occa≈øioned the parties being reduced; ≈øometimes not more than one officer, and two or three men, was thought the mo≈øt eligible mode to di≈øcover the movements of the enemy. A look-out boat was al≈øo ≈øtationed between the enemy's fleet and the Jer≈øey redoubt, to apprize the garri≈øon of any movement in the fleet. On the enemy's landing at the point, the General ordered all the provi≈øion and ≈øtores at Lake George Landing immediately removed into the lines; the batteaus and boats to be in readine≈øs to move to Fort George on the ≈øhorte≈øt notice. The enemy, advancing towards the lines, on the fir≈øt or ≈øecond day of July took po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the heights between the landing and the old French lines. The boats were ordered to move to Fort George, and the troops po≈øted at the landing and ≈øaw-mills ordered into the garri≈øon, which was effected without any lo≈øs. The communication between the garri≈øon and Lake George was now effectually cut off, the enemy being in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the heights in our front. Their light parties made frequent attacks on our picket, which con≈øi≈øted of fifty men, po≈øted ≈øome di≈øtance in front of the lines. On tho≈øe occa≈øions, and every other alarm that came to my knowledge (and I believe none e≈øcaped me) the General always appeared at the lines, going from right to left encouraging the troops, putting them in mind of the cau≈øe they were engaged in, telling them to keep them≈øelves cool, and not to throw away their fire if the enemy ≈øhould approach; that he wi≈øhed for nothing more than a ≈øerious attack, and did not doubt but we ≈øhould repul≈øe them if they did attack. Such was the General's per≈øonal attention to the po≈øts, and the movements of the enemy, after they landed at Three Mile Point, that I do not believe he ≈ølept one hour in four and twenty, on an average, till the evacuation took place. As to the quantity of provi≈øion I can ≈øay but little; but I recollect, ≈øoon after my arrival. General Schuyler's expre≈ø≈øing great ≈øurprize that no magazines were formed at Albany, or any other place nearer than that, for the ≈øupply of the garri≈øon. He ≈øent Mr. Yancey immediately to the country, and pre≈ø≈øed him in the ≈øtronge≈øt terms to ≈øpare no pains in obtaining provi≈øion for the po≈øt; that if the enemy ≈øhould come on, we ≈øhould be reduced by famine; adding, at the ≈øame time, that the neglect of the Commi≈ø≈øaries had been ≈øuch, that he believed it would be ≈øerving the public to hang at lea≈øt one of the department.‚ÄîThe following are the particulars I recollect re≈øpecting the retreat. About eight o'clock in the evening, July 5. I ≈øaw the ammunition and cannon removing on board the ve≈ø≈øels and to Mount Independence. I was at this time ignorant of the retreat. About nine o'clock the ≈øame evening General St. Clair ≈øent me with orders to General Fermoy, that he ≈øhould direct all the ≈øtores, ammunition, cannon, baggage, &c. to be taken to the foot of the hill on the ea≈øt ≈øide of the Mount, where they were to be put on board batteaus for Skeen≈øborough. I returned, after delivering the order, to Ticonderoga, and was ≈øent by the General with orders to the Officer in the Jer≈øey redoubt, to continue firing his cannon every half hour towards the battery the enemy were erecting oppo≈øite to the redoubt till further orders. About twelve o'clock the ≈øame evening I was again ≈øent to Mount Independence. I found General Fermoy near his hou≈øe, with his own baggage. I went to the landing, where I found Colonel Hay directing the loading the boats, with between three and four hundred men carrying down the ≈øtores, &c. but, for want of proper orders and attention from General Fermoy, every thing appeared in the greate≈øt confu≈øion. About this time they began to ≈øtrike their tents on Mount Independence, all of which, I believe, were put on board the boats. At two o'clock General St. Clair left Ticonderoga, all the ≈øtores, ammunition, artillery and camp equipage from that ≈øide being removed, except the heavy cannon, which, from our ≈ømall number of men and want of draught cattle, could not then be removed. All the tents and ho≈øpital ≈øtores, mo≈øt of the ammunition
and light cannon, were al≈øo removed from Mount Independence. Some provi≈øion, I cannot ≈øay what quantity, and mo≈øt of the heavy cannon, were left; all the batteaus and boats were however loaded. About three o'clock in the morning the troops were put in motion for the evacuation, but General Fermoy having ≈øet fire to his hou≈øe (contrary to po≈øitive orders) which lighted the whole Mount, and gave the enemy an opportunity of ≈øeeing every movement we made, it damped the ≈øpirits of our own troops; the militia regiments pu≈øhed out of the Mount in di≈øorder, and were followed by a number of continental troops; the guards from Ticonderoga had al≈øo to pa≈øs the light, and ru≈øhed forward in confu≈øion. The General at this time rode to the front, and obliged them to halt, and formed a line of march in rank and file, the roughne≈øs of the country and badne≈øs of the road permitting no other. Having effected this, he returned to the rear, which ≈øtill remained at the foot of the Mount. It was near four in the morning when the rear began to march. Colonel Francis, who commanded the rear guard, followed immediately after, and the line continued in good order till we arrived at Hubbarton, where the whole were halted to refre≈øh. The halt was near two hours. Mo≈øt of the ≈øtragglers and rear guard having joined us, the army was again put in motion. The rear guard here was given to Colonel Warner, with orders to halt about one and a half mile ≈øhort of the main body, which would remain that night at Ca≈øtle-Town, about ≈øix miles from Hubbarton, and to march in the morning by four, and join the main body. In the morning the General paraded the army, and waited near two hours for the rear guard. About ≈øeven o'clock a firing began on Warner's party, and on enquiry found he had halted at Hubbarton. The General expre≈ø≈øed his ≈øurprize that his orders were di≈øobeyed. He di≈øpatched my≈øelf and Major Living≈øton to order two militia regiments, that had halted between the main body and Warner, to reinforce him (the≈øe regiments were commanded by Colonel Bellows) and if the enemy ≈øhould appear in much ≈øuperior force, that Warner ≈øhould retreat to Rutland, where the main body would be to cover him. Tho≈øe regiments of militia refu≈øed to go up, tho' po≈øitively commanded, and afterwards intreated, by Colonel Bellows. This delay occa≈øioned Warner's retreat to Rutland, where the main body received him. The militia regiments returned, and although my≈øelf on hor≈øeback, and three miles from the main body, they arrived there with me. I rode expre≈øs.
Q. Court. Be≈øides the parties you have mentioned on fatigue, do you recollect whether there was a brigade ordered for fatigue on Mount Independence about the 23d of June?
A. I do recollect there was a brigade ordered for fatigue on Mount Independence about that time, which was exclu≈øive of the parties for fatigue I have mentioned.
Q. Do you know the time General St. Clair received information of the ≈øtrength and de≈øigns of the enemy?
A. I do not know the time.
Q. Did General St. Clair remove any of his baggage from Ticonderoga at any time previous to the evacuation?

A. No part of it. His ≈øon went off, I believe, about a week before, but did not even carry all his own baggage with him. About the time General St. Clair's ≈øon went away, General Fermoy's baggage was removed from Head-Quarters to Mount Independence, he having lived with the General until that time.
Q. What di≈øtance is Split-Rock from Ticonderoga?
A. About thirty-≈øeven miles.
Q. What di≈øtance is Gilliland's Creek from Ticonderoga?
A. About forty-two miles.
Lieutenant Colonel Living≈øton, Aid de Camp to General Schuyler, being ≈øworn, ≈øays:

About the middle of June, 1777, General St. Clair (agreeable to orders from General Schuyler) took upon him≈øelf the command of Ticonderoga and Mount Independence. A few days after I went to Ticonderoga, in company with General Schuyler. After being there a few days. General Schuyler found it nece≈ø≈øary for the ≈øervice to return to Albany, and the command in that department continued in General, St. Clair, with whom I had the honour of ≈øerving during the ≈øiege and on the retreat. Previous to the enemy's appearance before Ticonderoga, every method was made u≈øe of to gain intelligence of their movements and intentions. For this purpo≈øe ≈øcouting parties, properly officered, were kept out on the ea≈øt and we≈øt ≈øides of Lake Champlain. The≈øe parties were generally ≈øelected from a corps of rangers, who had been accu≈øtomed to ≈øervices of this kind. The General did not confine his attention to the article of intelligence alone. No mea≈øures were neglected to ≈øtrengthen the works on both ≈øides of the Lake. Fatigue parties were daily employed in this duty, and the direction of them generally committed to Colonel Ko≈øeiu≈øzko, an active officer, who acted as an a≈ø≈øi≈øtant engineer in the northern department. The ob≈øtructions of the navigation at Lake Champlain was al≈øo attended to. Be≈øides a very ≈ølight boom, which had been thrown acro≈øs the Lake during the command of General Gates, large ca≈ø≈øoons were ≈øunk between Mount Independence and Ticonderoga, altho' this arduous work was not compleated when the evacuation took place. On the 26th of June, or thereabouts, our ≈øcouts ob≈øerved an encampment of the enemy at Crown-Point, fifteen miles from Ticonderoga. From this time it became exceedingly difficult to procure any intelligence of the ≈øtrength or movements of the enemy, as the woods between us and Crown-Point were ≈øo infe≈øted with ≈øavages as to render it exceedingly hazardous to ≈øend ≈ømall parties that way, and the force of the garri≈øon was too weak to ju≈øtify the detaching a large number. Not many days after, I think it was on the la≈øt of June, the enemy's gun-boats appeared off Three Mile Point. The ≈øame day there was a ≈økirmi≈øh between a ≈øcout from the garri≈øon and the enemy. Our party were wor≈øted, and obliged to retire with a little lo≈øs. A con≈øiderable body of the enemy then took po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Mount-Hope. This height commanded the road between Ticonderoga and the North Landing of Lake George. It had been fortified by us the preceding year, but was di≈ømantled long before General St. Clair's arrival in that quarter. The old block-hou≈øe at the north end of Lake George was ≈øtill in our hands. A ≈øubaltern's guard was left in it, to protect the public ≈øtores which were lying at that landing. The enemy did not ≈øuffer this officer to remain long in peaceable po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion; they attacked him with ≈ømall arms, and were repul≈øed. The General, aware of the dangerous ≈øituation of the block-hou≈øe, and that the ≈ømall garri≈øon there mu≈øt ≈øoon be overpowered by numbers, or be obliged to ≈øubmit on the appearance of artillery, judged it nece≈ø≈øary to order them within the lines. This was effected ju≈øt in time, and without lo≈øs. The Communication between Ticonderoga and Lake George, by the main road, was now entirely cut off, which rendered it impracticable to bring the ≈øtores from the Lake within the fort. There was now
great danger of their falling into the enemy's hands. To prevent a lo≈øs of this kind, the General ordered the ≈øtores to be immediately put on board the batteaus, and carried back to Fort George, on the ≈øouth ≈øide of the Lake. This ≈øervice was executed without lo≈øs, and no further communication po≈ø≈øible between Ticonderoga and the country by the way of Lake George. The enemy continued to make their approaches on the Ticonderoga ≈øide of the Lake. It was impo≈ø≈øible, from the weakne≈øs of the garri≈øon, and the great extent of works we had to defend, to give them much interruption in their approaches. But the movement of the enemy, which gave the greate≈øt alarm to the garri≈øon, was the very rapid progre≈øs they made in clearing a road, and getting artillery on Sugar Hill or Mount Defiance. This proceeding was the more ≈øurpri≈øing, as it had been in agitation during the command of General Gates (in the fall of 1776, after our misfortune on Lake Champlain, when an attack on Ticonderoga was daily apprehended) to occupy that height with artillery, but was judged to be impracticable. This hill had ≈øuch an entire command of Ticonderoga, that the enemy might have counted our very numbers, and enfiladed every part of our works. After po≈ø≈øe≈øing them≈øelves of this commanding height, it would have required but a few hours more to inve≈øt us on all ≈øides. This might have been effected by only occupying the ground on the ea≈øt ≈øide of Lake Champlain below Mount Independence, where the pa≈øs from the Lake to Ea≈øt Creek is very narrow. Had this taken place, our communication with the country had been at an end, no further ≈øupplies of provi≈øion or men could have reached us, nor would a retreat, in ca≈øe of nece≈ø≈øity, then been practicable. But before this was effected, it was determined in a Council of War to retire from Ticonderoga and Mount Independence. This re≈øolution was entered into on the evening of the 5th of July, and very early in the morning of the 6th the troops left the ground. Mea≈øures for the evacuation were concerted with the greate≈øt ≈øecrecy, to keep the enemy ignorant of our de≈øigns. The centinels within the works were ordered to challenge no per≈øon that night. This order I carried my≈øelf to the guards on Ticonderoga, though I was ignorant of the rea≈øon of ≈øuch an order. The guns at the French lines were ≈øpiked; but, to amu≈øe the enemy, the Jer≈øey battery kept up a regular fire during the night. The General al≈øo ≈øent me to the old French redoubt, which commanded the bridge between Ticonderoga and the Mount, to order the officer commanding the artillery there not to ≈øpike the guns in that redoubt until further orders, as this redoubt might have been of ≈øervice in covering our troops on their pa≈ø≈øage acro≈øs the bridge; but I found that through ≈øome mi≈øtake tho≈øe guns had already been ≈øpiked. What ≈øtores it was po≈ø≈øible to remove in the cour≈øe of one night, or rather in the ≈øpace of a few hours, were put on board the ve≈ø≈øels and batteaus in Lake Champlain, and ≈øent for Skeen≈øborough under Colonel Long, with the invalids and ≈øick of the ho≈øpital. Many barrels of powder, in particular, I remember were taken from the magazine, and put on board the ve≈ø≈øels, though they afterwards fell into the enemy's hands, or were blown up. The remainder of the army, under General St. Clair him≈øelf, retired by land. The rear guard was under the command of Colonel Francis. The army the fir≈øt day reached Ca≈øtle-Town, about thirty miles from Mount Independence. We made a halt of between one and two hours at Hubbarton, twenty odd miles from the ≈øame place. Before our leaving that town, the General ordered the rear guard to halt a mile or two ≈øhort of Ca≈øtle-Town, where he intended to ≈øtay with the army that night. The General had no rea≈øon to doubt but the≈øe orders would have been attended to, and therefore was not a little ≈øurpri≈øed to find early the next morning that the rear guard was ≈øtill at Hubbarton, which is ≈øix miles di≈øtant from Ca≈øtle-Town. At this di≈øtance from the army, they were attacked by General Frazer's corps. The rear guard was increa≈øed by many who at fir≈øt did not belong to it. This was owing to the exce≈ø≈øive bad roads and very heavy marching, which prevented many, who were more feeble than others, from keeping pace with their regiments. The≈øe were picked up by the rear guard, agreeable to orders. At the time of the engagement, I imagine it could not amount to le≈øs than 1000 men. The moment the firing was heard at Ca≈øtle-Town, the General determined to ≈øupport the rear guard at Hubbarton. The troops at Ca≈øtle-Town were already under arms, and ready to march when the firing was fir≈øt heard. They were then ordered to keep their ground, and Major Dunn and my≈øelf were di≈øpatched with orders from the General to Colonel Bellows, who lay with his and another militia regiment between Ca≈øtle-Town and Hubbarton. Our orders were to direct Colonel Bellows to march with tho≈øe two regiments immediately to the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of Colonel Francis, and to a≈ø≈øure Colonel Bellows at the ≈øame time that they ≈øhould be farther ≈øupported, if nece≈ø≈øary. In riding towards Hubbarton we were met by the≈øe regiments which were marching with ≈øpeed towards Ca≈øtle-Town. We delivered our orders, but could not prevail upon either regiment to reinforce the rear guard; though, in ju≈øtice to Colonel Bellows, it mu≈øt be ≈øaid, he was in the rear of the regiment, and warmly per≈øuaded them to go to the field of action. an unaccountable panic had ≈øeized his men, and no commands or intreaties had any effect on them. Finding it impo≈ø≈øible to turn the≈øe regiments to this nece≈ø≈øary piece of ≈øervice, we rode on towards the ≈øeene of action, to find how matters were ≈øituated there, and report to the General; but we had not proceeded far before we were met by Capt. Chadwick, with about 30 men. Capt. Chadwick had ju≈øt left the field, and informed us that the action was at an end, that our men were di≈øper≈øed, that the communication between us and Hubbarton was cut on, ≈øo that we ≈øhould run the greate≈øt ri≈øque of being made pri≈øoners if we proceeded any further that way, and that the enemy were in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the field of battle, in great force. The firing (which had heen very ≈ømart) having cea≈øed, countenanced this intelligence, and we returned to Ca≈øtle-Town and apprized the General of it. General St. Clair now thought it unnece≈ø≈øary to ≈øend any further reinforcement to Hubbarton, and prepared to pur≈øue his march. But here I mu≈øt not forget to mention the conduct of the General towards two ea≈øtern regiments of militia, commanded, I believe, by Hale and Learned. The≈øe regiments had ≈øhewed much di≈øcentent on the march the preceding day, and began now to be very clamorous to be di≈ømi≈ø≈øed. The General, apprized of this ≈øpirit of di≈øcontent in the≈øe regiments, ordered them to be paraded at Ca≈øtle-Town, on the morning of the action at Hubbarton, and addre≈ø≈øed them in per≈øon. He ≈øpoke on this occa≈øion in ≈øo forcible and pathetic a manner, that the regiments, a≈øhamed of their conduct, con≈øented to remain with the army as long as there was any pro≈øpect of immediate danger from the enemy; but the plundering di≈øpo≈øition they di≈øcovered on the march, and their other di≈øorderly behaviour, obliged the General a day or two afterwards to di≈ømi≈øs them from the army with di≈øgrace. The army after this continued their route through ≈øeveral towns, ea≈øt of Ca≈øtle-Town, without any further interruption from the enemy, to Hud≈øon's River. I am very well per≈øwaded that it was General St. Clair's intention at fir≈øt to have marched by Skeen≈øborough to Fort Edward; but an officer of one of our gallies on the Lake arrived
at Ca≈øtle-Town before we left it, and informed the General that the enemy were pur≈øuing in force that way, who would reach Skeen≈øborough before he could po≈ø≈øibly get there, and that ≈øome ve≈ø≈øels had already fallen into their power. This determined the General to change his intended route, and take the road he afterwards did. Before we reached Hud≈øon's River, General St. Clair di≈øpatched me to inform General Schuyler of the ≈øituation of his army. So far as I had an opportunity of ob≈øerving General St. Clair's conduct, it reflects high honour on him. Previous to, during the ≈øiege, and on the retreat, he gave proofs of his attention, activity and courage. The garri≈øon were always under arms at their proper po≈øts before ≈øun-ri≈øe, and frequently before day-break. The General was always out on the≈øe occa≈øions him≈øelf, and was an example of vigilance to the ≈øoldiery. I do not remember, tho' I lived in the ≈øame quarters with him the greater part of the time during the ≈øiege, that he ever undre≈ø≈øed him≈øelf at night. All night, indeed, he would ≈øcarcely ever permit him≈øelf to ≈øleep. If he did, it was not above an hour or two, tho' the gentlemen about him would frequently ob≈øerve that he would certainly injure his health unle≈øs he indulged him≈øelf with more ≈øleep. In ca≈øe of alarms, which were very frequent, he always appeared at the lines, encouraging the ≈øoldiery by his pre≈øence and exhortations. On the retreat, he pre≈øerved as much order in the army as was po≈ø≈øible thro' ≈øuch bad roads, and ≈øo rough a country.
Q. Do you know the time General St. Clair received information of the ≈øtrength and de≈øigns of the enemy?
